unnormalised: Dr. Meera Sharma, a leading cardiologist at AIIMS, Delhi, has been awarded the 'Healthcare Innovator of the Year' at the National Medical Conference held on 10/11/2024.
normalised: Doctor Meera Sharma, a leading cardiologist at A-I-I-M-S, Delhi, has been awarded the 'Healthcare Innovator of the Year' at the National Medical Conference held on tenth November two thousand and twenty four.

unnormalised: The award recognizes Dr. Sharma's pioneering work in non-invasive cardiac procedures. Her research has significantly reduced recovery times for patients suffering from heart ailments. "It's an absolute honour," said Dr. Sharma, beaming after receiving the award. "This recognition fuels my commitment to pushing the boundaries of cardiac care."
normalised: The award recognizes Doctor Sharma's pioneering work in non-invasive cardiac procedures. Her research has significantly reduced recovery times for patients suffering from heart ailments. "It's an absolute honour," said Doctor Sharma, beaming after receiving the award. "This recognition fuels my commitment to pushing the boundaries of cardiac care."

unnormalised: Prof. Rajesh Kumar, head of the cardiology department at PGI Chandigarh, lauded Dr. Sharma's dedication. "Dr. Sharma's work is truly groundbreaking. Her innovative techniques have not only improved patient outcomes but have also made cardiac care more accessible, especially in rural areas." Prof. Kumar added that the impact of her research is immense and she is doing a great job in the field.
normalised: Professor Rajesh Kumar, head of the cardiology department at P-G-I Chandigarh, lauded Doctor Sharma's dedication. "Doctor Sharma's work is truly groundbreaking. Her innovative techniques have not only improved patient outcomes but have also made cardiac care more accessible, especially in rural areas." Professor Kumar added that the impact of her research is immense and she is doing a great job in the field.

unnormalised: The announcement also highlights concerns over the rising incidence of cardiovascular diseases in India. Experts, including Dr. A.K. Verma, a renowned physician, stress the importance of early detection and preventative measures. "Lifestyle changes, regular check-ups, and awareness campaigns are crucial in combating this growing health crisis," Dr. Verma emphasized. He pointed out that conditions such as high blood pressure and diabetes are major risk factors, requiring immediate attention.
normalised: The announcement also highlights concerns over the rising incidence of cardiovascular diseases in India. Experts, including Doctor A. K. Verma, a renowned physician, stress the importance of early detection and preventative measures. "Lifestyle changes, regular check-ups, and awareness campaigns are crucial in combating this growing health crisis," Doctor Verma emphasized. He pointed out that conditions such as high blood pressure and diabetes are major risk factors, requiring immediate attention.

unnormalised: Adding to the discussion, Nurse Aisha Khan from Apollo Hospital, Mumbai, shared her perspective on the daily challenges faced in patient care. "We often see patients who delay seeking treatment due to various reasons, including financial constraints and lack of awareness," she said. "Educating the community about the importance of timely intervention is essential."
normalised: Adding to the discussion, Nurse Aisha Khan from Apollo Hospital, Mumbai, shared her perspective on the daily challenges faced in patient care. "We often see patients who delay seeking treatment due to various reasons, including financial constraints and lack of awareness," she said. "Educating the community about the importance of timely intervention is essential."

unnormalised: The award ceremony was attended by numerous dignitaries, including representatives from the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. The minister, Shri. Harshvardhan Patil, reiterated the government's commitment to investing in healthcare infrastructure and supporting research initiatives aimed at improving the nation's health outcomes.
normalised: The award ceremony was attended by numerous dignitaries, including representatives from the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. The minister, Shri. Harshvardhan Patil, reiterated the government's commitment to investing in healthcare infrastructure and supporting research initiatives aimed at improving the nation's health outcomes.

unnormalised: Several other healthcare professionals were also recognized for their contributions, including Ms. Priya Singh, a dedicated social worker who has been instrumental in organizing health camps in underserved communities and working as a bridge between the doctors and patients. The event concluded with a pledge to continue working collaboratively towards a healthier India.
